Abstract The PAMELA satellite-borne experiment has presented new results on
cosmic-ray antiparticles that can be interpreted in terms of DM annihilation or pulsar
contribution. The instrument was launched from the Baikonur cosmodrome and it
has been collecting data since July 2006. The combination of a permanent magnet
silicon strip spectrometer and a silicon-tungsten imaging calorimeter allows precision
studies of the charged cosmic radiation to be conducted over a wide energy range
with high statistics. The primary scientific goal is the measurement of the antiproton
and positron energy spectrum in order to search for exotic sources. PAMELA is also
searching for primordial antinuclei (anti-helium), and testing cosmic-ray propagation
models through precise measurements of the antiparticle energy spectrum and
precision studies of light nuclei and their isotopes. This talk illustrates the most recent
scientific results obtained by the PAMELA experiment.
Keywords Cosmic rays · Antimatter · Dark matter

physics " [1]) is a satellite-borne experiment conceived to study charged particles in
the cosmic radiation. In particular, it has been designed and optimized to measure

the rare antimatter component in a wide energy interval, ranging from several tens
of MeV to some hundreds of GeV, and with unprecedented precision and sensitivity.
Antiprotons and positrons, expected to be created mostly in the interaction of
cosmic-rays (CR) with the interstellar medium (ISM), are fundamental in studies
of production and propagation of CR in the Galaxy, providing complementary
information to light nuclei, originated through spallation reactions of heavier nuclei.
Differently, the antiproton production is characterized by a relatively high kinematic
threshold, and reflects the propagation history of the dominant proton component
of the cosmic radiation. Additionally, the propagation of electrons and positrons is
governed by mechanisms different from those of CR nuclei, allowing the electromag-
netic conditions encountered during the transport in the Galaxy to be studied.
Moreover, CR antiparticle measurements have been long considered as one of
the most promising tools for indirect dark matter (DM) searches, since DM particles
should annihilate or decay into products as neutrinos, photons, protons, antiprotons,
electrons and positrons. Predicted DM antiproton and positron fluxes could be
detectable above the background from nuclear interactions through a distortion of
the measured spectra, and such excess of cosmic antimatter may be detected in space-
based or balloon-borne experiments.
Indeed, the observation of CR antiparticles allows the investigation of the global
matter/antimatter symmetry of the Universe. In case of existence of antigalaxies,
signals of antimatter could be detected in the extragalactic component of the cosmic
radiation. While CR antiprotons can be used to probe some intrinsic properties of
antimatter (lower limit on the decay lifetime [2]), only the detection of antinuclei
with Z≥2 would provide direct evidence of the existence of antimatter domains in
the Universe. PAMELA design sensitivity allows to accurately measure the ¯
He/He
flux ratio in a large rigidity interval.
Finally, concomitant scientific goals of the PAMELA experiment concern the
study of solar modulation, by investigating low energy (anti)particles in the cosmic
radiation during the 24
th solar minimum, and the study of CR interaction with the
Earth's magnetosphere.
2 The PAMELA experiment
PAMELA is in orbit since 15 June 2006, when it was launched from the Baikonur
cosmodrome on board the " Resurs-DK1 " satellite. The apparatus is housed inside
an aluminum pressurized container, with a maximum thickness of 2 mm in corre-
spondence of the PAMELA acceptance window. PAMELA comprises a number of
sub-detectors with specific tasks (see Fig. 1), in order to identify antiparticles with
high accuracy, over the large background from the most abundant CR components.
The central part of the instrument is the magnetic spectrometer, which allows a
precise determination of the sign, absolute value of charge Z and rigidity (R = pc/Ze)
of incident particles. It consists of a hollow 0.43 T permanent magnet (Nd-Fe-B) and
of a set of six silicon microstrip sensor planes, uniformly positioned along the cavity.
These detectors are provided with a sensitive layer on both upper (X or bending
view) and lower side (Y or not-bending view), with the implanted strips of one side
orthogonal to those of the other, allowing the independent measurement of both the
X and Y coordinates of the crossing point of an incident ionizing particle, with a

a Maximum Detectable Rigidity (MDR, defined as the value for which the relative
uncertainty is 100%) of about 1 TV.
An electromagnetic calorimeter, located below the spectrometer, provides sepa-
ration of hadrons and leptons by means of their interaction pattern when traversing
the detector. It consists of 22 planes, each made up of a central tungsten absorber
of thickness 2.6 mm sandwiched between two 380 μm thick silicon detectors. The
spatial development of a shower is reconstructed by the layers of silicon detectors
which are divided into strips in alternating directions for each plane. The total depth
of the calorimeter amounts to 16.3 radiation lengths (0.6 nuclear interaction lengths),
so both electrons and positrons develop a well-contained electromagnetic shower
below some hundreds of GeV.
A time-of-flight (TOF) measurement is performed by a set of fast plastic scintilla-
tors arranged in three planes (S1, S2 and S3), with alternate layers placed orthogonal
to each other. The measured TOF resolution of ∼300 ps allows particle identification
below 1 GV, and the rejection of albedo particles with a significance of ∼30 standard
deviations. Indeed, it is used to determine the absolute value of charge Z of incident
particles through the multiple measurement of energy loss dE/dx in the scintillator
counters. Moreover, it provides a fast signal for triggering data acquisition in the
whole instrument.
A further scintillator plane (S4) is placed below the calorimeter, and it is used
both to detect showers not contained in the calorimeter and to detect high energy
(>100 GeV) out-of-acceptance electrons together with the calorimeter information.
The electron-hadron discrimination capabilities of the calorimeter are comple-
mented by a neutron detector (ND), which exploits the much larger neutron pro-
duction originated in the hadronic showers respect to the electromagnetic showers.

It is made up of of 36 proportional counters filled with
3 He and surrounded by a
polyethylene moderator enveloped in a thin cadmium layer.
Finally, PAMELA is equipped with an anticounter system composed of three
sets of plastic scintillators: the CARD, which consists of four lateral detectors
surrounding the volume between S1 and S2; the CAT, formed by a single top detector
placed around S2; and the CAS, composed by four lateral detectors covering the sides
of the spectrometer. They delimit the apparatus geometric acceptance and are used
to identify false triggers, generated by secondary particles produced in the apparatus.
3 Identification capabilities
The particle identification with the PAMELA experiment is based on a good track
determination provided by the tracking system, fundamental to achieve a reliable
charge sign separation and a precise estimate of the particle rigidity, in order to
separate antiparticles from the much more abundant flux of protons, electrons and
light nuclei. Strict conditions were applied on the number of position measurements
from the tracker and on the χ
2 associated to the tracking fit procedure, in order
to reject events which were wrongly reconstructed due to scattering, minimizing
uncertainties on the rigidity measurement.
The analysis of the interaction topology in the calorimeter is crucial to allow
hadron/lepton discrimination. The used criteria are based on several features describ-
ing an electromagnetic shower development in the calorimeter which, combined with
dE/dx measurements from the individual silicon strips, allow electrons and positrons
to be identified with high precision and efficiency. The residual proton contamination
in the positron sample was estimated with statistical methods [3, 4].
Strong constraints on the combined information from several detectors of
PAMELA were used in order to get a clean antiparticle sample from the recorded
data. Secondary particles produced by CR interacting in the Al vessel or at the
support structures in the upper parts of the apparatus were rejected by exploiting
the TOF and the tracking systems segmentation, and by requiring no activity in
the anticoincidence scintillators. In the case of antiprotons, the particle velocity
measurement provided by the TOF and the ionization loss in both the tracker and
the TOF planes were used to reject electrons, wrongly reconstructed protons and
locally produced particles (mostly π
− ). The residual contamination was estimated
with simulations to be about 10% in the rigidity range 1÷3 GV and negligible
elsewhere [5, 6].
Because of the finite spectrometer resolution (MDR ∼ 1 TV), high rigidity protons
may be assigned the wrong sign of curvature. Such " spillover " protons determine the
highest energy at which antiprotons can be unambiguously measured by PAMELA.
To reduce this background, strict requirements were applied on the quality of the
tracks reconstructed in the spectrometer. In particular, the MDR related to each
track, evaluated on an event-by-event basis by propagating the estimated coordinate
errors and taking into account the track topology, was required to be six times larger
than the measured rigidity. This allowed the antiproton measurement to be extended
up to 180 GV with a small contamination from spillover protons [6].

account losses in the apparatus due to hadronic interactions, multiple scattering and

4 Results
4.1 Antiprotons
The PAMELA collaboration has recently published its antiproton flux and its
updated antiproton-to-proton flux ratio measurements in the kinetic energy range
60 MeV ÷ 180 GeV [5, 6]. They significantly improve data by previous experiments,
thanks to the high statistical significance and the large explored interval, with the
extension of antiproton measurements to high energies (above 50 GeV).
The ¯
p flux and the ¯
p/ p ratio are shown respectively on the left and on the right
panel of Fig. 2, where they are compared with data from contemporary experiments
[8–13] and some theoretical calculations for a pure secondary production of antipro-
tons during the propagation of CR in the Galaxy [14–16]. PAMELA data reproduce
the expected peak around ∼2 GeV in the antiproton spectrum and appear to be
consistent with pure secondary calculations, excluding an appreciable contribution
from exotic processes in that energy range.

4.4 Geomagnetically trapped antiprotons
The satellite orbit (70
• inclination and 350÷610 km altitude) allows a very detailed
measurement of the cosmic radiation in different regions of the terrestrial magne-
tosphere to be performed by PAMELA, including information about the nature
and energy spectra of under-cutoff
1 particles [35]. In particular, the spacecraft orbit
passes through the South Atlantic Anomaly (SAA), allowing the observation of
geomagnetically trapped particles from the inner radiation belt.
Antiprotons are created in reactions of energetic CR with the Earth's atmosphere.
Part of these particles are captured by the geomagnetic field allowing the forma-
tion of an antiproton radiation belt around the Earth. In particular, a dominant
contribution from decay of albedo antineutrons has been hypothesized [36]. The
geomagnetically trapped antiproton population has been observed for the first time
by the PAMELA experiment [37]. The data show the existence of a significant
antiproton flux in the SAA below ∼1 GeV in kinetic energy: at the current solar
minimum, the trapped flux exceeds the galactic CR antiproton flux and the mean
atmospheric (under-cutoff) antiproton spectrum outside radiation belts by three
and four orders of magnitude respectively, thereby constituting the most abundant
antiproton source near the Earth. Results are reported in Fig. 4. PAMELA data
allow CR transport models to be tested in the terrestrial atmosphere and significantly
constrain predictions from trapped antiproton models.

5 Theoretical interpretations of PAMELA ¯
p and e
+ data
The unexpected rising positron fraction measured by the PAMELA experiment has
triggered a considerable amount of possible interpretations based on the existence of
some standard or exotic primary sources. These models are significantly constrained
by antiproton data which, contrarily, appear to be in agreement with predictions
of a purely secondary production. Further limits are provided by the measurement
of diffuse gamma rays. In addition, calculations of the positron fraction suffer from
large theoretical uncertainties, which have to be taken into account to estimate the
significance of proposed mechanisms.
5.1 Theoretical uncertainties on " standard " positron fraction
Secondary positrons are created by spallation reactions of CR nuclei on interstellar
gas and propagate in a diffusive mode under the influence of the turbulent com-
ponent of the galactic magnetic field. Consequently, estimates are strongly affected
by uncertainties about cosmic nuclei spectra, nuclear cross sections involved in
the positron production mechanism and propagation parameters involved in the
diffusion equation. Indeed, the secondary positron production depends on the spatial
distribution of CR nuclei and of the ISM, and fluctuations of the local injection rate
can influence some features in the measured spectrum. Moreover, a crucial ingredi-
ent for the calculation is given by the electron flux [38], with further complications
arising from the lack of knowledge about different spectral contributions, including
primary electrons from astrophysical sources, and about solar modulation effects.
5.2 Astrophysical sources
Regardless of theoretical uncertainties, the presence of an excess appears manifest
and consistent. As already proposed several years ago [39], a possible enhancement
of the e
± flux could be explained by astrophysical sources like nearby pulsars
[40, 41] (see left panel of Fig. 5). In this scenario, electrons are believed to be
initially extracted from the surface of the star by the intense rotation induced
electric fields and later to produce e
± pairs via electromagnetic showers inside the
magnetosphere; in addition, e
± are possibly re-accelerated by the pulsar winds or
in the supernova remnant shocks and released in the ISM [39, 42, 43]. Hence, no
sizeable contribution from antiprotons is predicted, while counterparts in γ -rays are
expected. In particular, magnetars are thought to generate a large amount of e
± pairs,
giving an important contribution despite their relatively low abundance [44]. Other
possible sources are given by nearby gamma-ray burst (GRB), GRB-like pulsars and
microquasar [45].
Alternatively, positrons can be created as secondary products of hadronic inter-
actions inside supernova remnants (SNRs). The secondary production takes place
in the same region where CR are being accelerated: secondary e
± participate in the
acceleration process and result in a very flat spectrum at high energy, thus providing a
natural explanation for the observed positron excess, after propagation in the Galaxy
has been taken into account. In particular, old SNRs appear the best candidates [46]
(see right panel of Fig. 5). On the other hand, counterparts in γ -rays and possibly
in the antiproton channel as well are expected [47]. The predicted antiproton flux,

5.3 Dark matter annihilation or decay
The DM possibility, with annihilations in the halo of the Milky Way providing the
anomalous antiparticle flux, is of great interest from the particle physics viewpoint.
Minimal DM models can give a reasonably good fit to the PAMELA positron
data, while antiprotons data put strong constraints on DM annihilations, disfavoring
channels with gauge bosons, Higgs bosons or quarks. Nevertheless, the required hard
spectrum would result by combining a very high DM particle mass (∼10 TeV) and
text.note: The PAMELA space mission for antimatter and dark matter searches in space
text.body:
a very efficient enhancement mechanism for the annihilation into charged gauge
bosons [49]. In particular, annihilating DM particles with ∼1 TeV mass or heavier
have been proposed in order to accommodate the observations of Fermi [29] and
provide the PAMELA positron excess. Super-heavy DM candidates would also
result in correct thermal relic abundance [50].
Alternatively, DM models assuming a dominant leptonic channel can fit
PAMELA positron and antiproton measurements as well [40, 49]. In pure e
± models
the DM annihilation yields a pair of monochromatic e
± , with injection energies equal
to the mass of the annihilating DM particle. " Lepto-philic " models assume an equal
pair-annihilation branching ratio into each charged lepton species. Indeed, multistate
DM models with small mass splittings and couplings to light hidden sector bosons
have been proposed as an explanation for the high energy lepton excesses [51, 52].
Provided some modifications concerning underlying distribution of the DM or the
propagation of its annihilation products, and given the inherent astrophysical un-
certainties, a wino-like neutralino of mass about 200 GeV, non-thermally produced,
normalized to the local relic density, and annihilating mainly into W-bosons, appears
to be a plausible candidate [53], consistent with existing positron, antiproton and γ -
ray data (see Fig. 6). Neutralinos with much larger mass do not fit to the PAMELA
results unless very large astrophysical boost factors are employed [54].
Another possibility is offered by Kaluza-Klein models with one universal extra
dimension [55]. The DM particles annihilate largely to charged leptons, which
enables them to produce a spectrum of CR electrons and positrons consistent with
the PAMELA and ATIC [30] measurements, regardless of large boost factors and
significant annihilation to hadronic modes. Corresponding masses are limited to
approximately 600 ÷ 900 GeV by relic abundance arguments.
Radiative corrections may considerably enhance the DM induced positron yield
and result in a pronounced spectral signature, a rising positron to electron ratio and a
sharp cutoff in the positron spectrum at the neutralino mass. Again, very large boost
factors have to be invoked to obtain such a spectral feature [56].
6 Conclusions
The recently released PAMELA antiparticle data have significant implications in the
fields of astrophysics, particle physics and cosmology, putting strong constraints for
theoretical models of CR production and propagation and for the existence of exotic
processes. In contrast with antiproton measurements, the observed unambiguous
positron excess appears inconsistent with the predictions of the standard model for
the origin and propagation of CR in the Galaxy, regardless of theoretical uncertain-
ties affecting calculations. In the attempt to account for such excess, several scenarios
have been put forward, with the most exciting possibility involving DM particles
annihilation or decay. Alternatively, the pulsars/SNRs hypothesis encompases the
positron fraction data with conservative assumptions.
